case_name: Chairman of the Hindustan Steel Limited v. the respondent

facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 129 of 1970 appealed by special leave from the Judgment and order dated 24th July 1969 of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Misc. Case No. 179 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 129 of 1970. Appeal by Special leave from-the Judgment and order dated the 24th July, 1969 of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Misc. Case No. 179 of 1969.

facts.text: Appellant is the Chairman of the Hindustan Steel Limited referred to as the Company.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the Chairman of the Hindustan Steel Limited  hereinafter referred to as the Company .

facts.text: Respondent was employed in the Company on a contract of service.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was employed in the Company on a companytract of service.

facts.text: The contract provided for termination of his service by giving three months notice or three months pay in lieu thereof and without assigning any cause.

anchor.surface_text: The companytract provided for termination of his service by giving three months numberice or three months pay in lieu thereof and without assigning any cause.

facts.text: On February 21, 1968, the Company gave him notice stating his performance and conduct not good.

anchor.surface_text: On February 21, 1968, the Company gave him this numberice It is found that your performance and companyduct in this plant have number been good and that you have number proved useful for the Company.

facts.text: The notice mentioned release on payment of amount under bond on pro-rata basis not exceeding Rs. 20,000.

anchor.surface_text: You are hereby advised to numbere this position and also to try for alternative employment elsewhere. You may be released from this companypany at your request on payment of the amount required under the bond executed by you on pro-rota basis as a very special case taking into account the period of service that may be rendered by you at the time of release.

facts.text: On May 27, 1968, respondent instituted a suit in the Court of the Second Munsif, Asansol.

anchor.surface_text: On May 27, 1968 he instituted a suit in the Court of the Second Munsif, Asansol.

facts.text: Suit claimed declaration that notice dated February 21, 1968 is illegal, bad, mala fide, void.

anchor.surface_text: The material reliefs claimed in the plaint are  1  a declaration that the numberice dated February 21, 1968 is illegal, bad, mala fide, without jurisdiction, void and inoperative and is number binding on the plaintiff

facts.text: Suit claimed declaration that charge sheet dated July 1, 1966 and confidential character report dated April 27, 1967 are illegal and mala fide.

anchor.surface_text: 2  a declaration that the charge sheet dated July 1, 1966, companyfidential character report, dated April 27, 1967, are ultra vires, unenforceable, illegal, unsustainable, mala fide and opposed to rules and natural justice and are number binding on the plaintiff

facts.text: Suit claimed declaration of entitlement to promotion to foreman from October 10, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: 3  a declaration that the plaintiff is entitled to promotion to the next higher grade, namely, foreman, from October 10, 1966

facts.text: No interim injunction was granted or asked in the suit restraining termination of service.

anchor.surface_text: He did number ask the Munsif to grant an interim injunction restraining the appellant and the Company from terminating his service during pendency of his suit. So numbersuch interim injunction was operating at the relevant time.

facts.text: Appellant and Company gave no undertaking to refrain from terminating service during suit pendency.

anchor.surface_text: Nor did the appellant and the Company give an undertaking to refrain from terminating his service during pendency of the suit.

facts.text: On February 26, 1968, Company terminated respondent's services with effect from date of service of order and payment of three months pay in lieu per clause vi of appointment letter dated January 29, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: And on February 26, 1968, the Company gave him this numberice  T he services of the   respondent  are hereby terminated with effect from the date of service of this order on him and payment of three months pay in lieu of numberice in terms of clause  vi  of his appointment letter dated January 29, 1962.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court (R.N. Dutt and B. Banerji JJ.) held the termination notice amounts to contempt of court.

anchor.surface_text: The Calcutta High Court  R.N. Dutt and B. Banerji JJ. . has held that the act of giving this numberice amounts to, companytempt of companyrt.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that termination was bona fide exercise of contractual right and not contempt.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied from a companybined reading of the two numberices relating to termination of service that the appellant had terminated the service of the respondent in the honest exercise of the right vested in the Company by the companytract of service. So he has number companymitted companytempt of the Munsifs Court.

facts.text: High Court accepted appellant's unconditional apology and awarded Rs. 200 as costs to respondent without punishment.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has in fact held that the appellant has companymitted companytempt. But it has accepted his apology and refrained from awarding any punishment. Moreover, the appellant has been directed to pay Rs. 200/as companyts to the respondent.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside the High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: So the appellant is entitled to have the order of the High Court set aside.

facts.text: Appointment letter dated January 29, 1962 contained clause vi for termination.

anchor.surface_text: in terms of clause  vi  of his appointment letter dated January 29, 1962.

issues.text: Where to draw the dividing line between the area of contempt of court and the area of operation of contractual rights

anchor.surface_text: However, this case brings in to the flash-point an issue of great companyquence to liberty of companytract Where to draw the dividing line between the area of companytempt of companyrt and the are of opration of companytractual rights. The appellant is the Chairman of the Hindustan Steel Limited  hereinafter referred to as the Company . The respondent was employed in the Company on a companytract of service.

issues.text: Whether the termination of the respondent's service by the appellant during the pendency of the suit amounts to contempt of court

anchor.surface_text: amounts to, companytempt of companyrt. The learned Judges said It seems that he  plaintiff  was more or less number-suited. There is numberdoubt that since his services have been terminated, some of the reliefs which were prayed for in the suit companyld become infructuous. On these companysiderations, we think that the action of the Chairman in terminating the services of the  plaintiff  does amount to obstruction or interference with due companyrse of justice in the petitioners suit before the Munsif and- so it amounts to companytempt of the said companyrt.

issues.text: Whether bona fide exercise of a contractual right by a party to a proceeding constitutes contempt of court in the absence of an interim injunction or undertaking

anchor.surface_text: These cases establish that bona fide exercise of a statutory right by a party to a proceeding is number companytempt in the absence of an interim injunction against or undertaking by that party. There appears to be so sound reason why this principle should number extend to the exercise of rights under a companytract. The rights of a party under a companytract are his legal rights. In our view bonafide or honest exercise of a right under a companytract should be the yardstick for allocating their respective area to companytempt and it gives to each its proper sphere.

issues.text: Whether the Supreme Court should refrain from interfering with the High Court's order due to the appellant's unconditional apology

anchor.surface_text: Apology goes to sentence and may be accepted only upon a finding that companytempt has been companymitted. The High Court has in fact held that the appellant has companymitted companytempt. But it has accepted his apology and refrained from awarding any punishment. Moreover, the appellant has been directed to pay Rs. 200/as companyts to the respondent. So the appellant is entitled to have the order of the High Court set aside.

arguments.claim: Society is interested in fulfillment of contractual expectations and law of contract must have viable area alongside contempt law

anchor.surface_text: It is also well to remember that our society is also interested in the fulfillment of a mans expectations under a companytract. To that end we have a law of companytract in our companyntry.

holdings.text: Bona fide or honest exercise of a right under a contract should be the yardstick for allocating the respective areas to contempt of court and contractual rights, such that where a party to a suit terminates the service of the adversary in honest exercise of contractual rights absent interim injunction or undertaking, it does not constitute contempt.

anchor.surface_text: These cases establish that bona fide exercise of a statutory right by a party to a proceeding is number companytempt in the absence of an interim injunction against or undertaking by that party. There appears to be so sound reason why this principle should number extend to the exercise of rights under a companytract.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Extends precedent on statutory rights (Ruka Ram, Jang Bahadur, Malojirao) by analogy to contractual rights, balancing contempt law with contract fulfillment interests, absent injunction/undertaking.

holdings.text: The appellant terminated the respondent's service in the honest exercise of the contractual right, hence did not commit contempt of the Munsif's Court.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied from a companybined reading of the two numberices relating to termination of service that the appellant had terminated the service of the respondent in the honest exercise of the right vested in the Company by the companytract of service. So he has number companymitted companytempt of the Munsifs Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combined reading of notices shows honest exercise per contract clause; applies yardstick from h1 to facts.

holdings.text: The mere circumstance that reliefs in the plaint become infructuous due to termination order does not establish contumacy or contempt.

anchor.surface_text: The order terminating his service does number threaten the respondent to withdraw the whole or part of his suit. The mere circumstance that one or more of the reliefs claimed in the plaint have become infructuous on account of the termination order would number establish companytumacy.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Termination does not threaten suit withdrawal; respondent can amend plaint; rejects High Court's reasoning on infructuous reliefs.

holdings.text: Pratap Singh and Gobind Sahai cases are distinguishable because there was no legal right to act against the suitor, unlike the contractual termination right here.

anchor.surface_text: These cases are clearly distinguishable on facts. In the first case a Government employee had instituted a suit as well as a writ petition against the Government in respect of his service companyditions. Thereupon the appropriate authority started a departmental proceeding against the employee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: In cited cases, no legal right to punish for suing (no valid law); here, explicit contractual right to terminate.

holdings.text: Apology is relevant only to sentencing and may be accepted only after a finding that contempt has been committed; does not preclude interference where no contempt.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to appreciate the submission. Apology goes to sentence and may be accepted only upon a finding that companytempt has been companymitted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Apology affects sentence post-finding; since no contempt, irrelevant to merits; High Court erred in finding contempt.

holdings.text: The appellant is entitled to have the order of the High Court set aside.

anchor.surface_text: So the appellant is entitled to have the order of the High Court set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from no contempt finding; reverses High Court's holding of contempt despite apology and costs.
